title: Miracles of Deliverance
shortSummary: Mark chapter 5 recounts two powerful miracles of Jesus demonstrating His authority over evil and death. First, Jesus delivers a man possessed by many demons, showing His power to restore life and sanity. Then, He heals a woman suffering from a chronic illness and raises a synagogue ruler's daughter from the dead, revealing His compassion and divine authority.
timeline: c. AD 30 - Ministry of Jesus in the region of the Gadarenes and Decapolis

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God who demonstrates His divine authority through miracles of healing and deliverance.

keyCharacters.name: Legion (the possessed man)
keyCharacters.description: A man possessed by many demons who lived among the tombs until Jesus set him free.

keyCharacters.name: Jairus
keyCharacters.description: A synagogue ruler who earnestly seeks Jesus to heal his dying daughter.

keyCharacters.name: The woman with the issue of blood
keyCharacters.description: A woman suffering for twelve years from a bleeding condition who is healed by faith when she touches Jesus’ garment.

definitions.definition: A Roman military term referring to a large unit of soldiers; here it symbolizes the many demons possessing the man.
A demonic or evil spirit considered ritually impure and opposed to God’s holiness.
A chronic bleeding condition considered both medically and ceremonially defiling under Jewish law.
An Aramaic phrase meaning 'Damsel, I say unto thee, arise,' spoken by Jesus when raising Jairus’ daughter.

outline.heading: Jesus Heals the Demoniac
outline.description: Jesus crosses to the region of the Gadarenes and encounters a man possessed by many demons named Legion. Jesus commands the spirits to leave, sending them into a herd of swine, which then drown. The man is restored to his right mind and sent to testify about Jesus’ mercy.

outline.heading: Jairus’ Plea for His Daughter
outline.description: Jairus, a synagogue ruler, approaches Jesus urgently, pleading for healing for his dying daughter. Jesus agrees to go with him, followed by a large crowd.

outline.heading: The Woman Healed by Faith
outline.description: A woman suffering from a bleeding condition for twelve years touches Jesus’ garment in faith and is instantly healed. Jesus acknowledges her faith publicly, affirming the power of belief.

outline.heading: Jesus Raises Jairus’ Daughter
outline.description: Despite news that Jairus’ daughter has died, Jesus encourages faith and raises her from the dead, demonstrating His authority over death and bringing great astonishment.

application: Trust in Jesus’ power to deliver from spiritual bondage, knowing He can restore even the most broken lives.
Approach Jesus with faith and persistence in prayer, as Jairus and the bleeding woman did, believing in His compassion and ability to heal.
Recognize that Jesus’ timing may differ from ours, but His command to 'Be not afraid, only believe' calls us to trust Him in all circumstances.
Share testimonies of God’s work in your life to encourage others, following the example of the healed demoniac.

keyVerses.text: Howbeit Jesus suffered him not, but saith unto him, Go home to thy friends, and tell them how great things the Lord hath done for thee, and hath had compassion on thee.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of testimony and proclaiming God’s mercy after experiencing His deliverance.

keyVerses.text: And he said unto her, Daughter, thy faith hath made thee whole; go in peace, and be whole of thy plague.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus emphasizes that faith is the key to receiving healing and peace, encouraging believers to trust Him fully.

keyVerses.text: As soon as Jesus heard the word that was spoken, he saith unto the ruler of the synagogue, Be not afraid, only believe.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches believers to replace fear with faith, trusting Jesus’ power even in seemingly hopeless situations.

keyVerses.text: And he took the damsel by the hand, and said unto her, Talitha cumi; which is, being interpreted, Damsel, I say unto thee, arise.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus’ command over death is powerfully demonstrated here, affirming His divine authority and ability to give life.
